note.p: Literally meaning “latticework grid door,” gezi men is one of the traditional door forms in Chinese architecture. It derives its name from the lattice panels installed in its upper section. Documented in both the Yingzao fashi and Zirenyizhi （Li 2009, 7.1b-3b; Xue 1522, 3518.4a-16b）, representations of lattice doors can also be found in Tang dynasty paintings, such as Li Sixun's 'River Boats and Pavilions' (Jiangfan louge tu). This door type and the term “lattice door”continued to be used through the Qing dynasty. Official Qing documents usually refer to it as ge shan 槅扇.

According to the Yingzao fashi, lattice doors typically ranged from 1.88 to 3.76 meters in height, with a height-to-width ratio of approximately 10:3. Each bay usually contained four door leaves, though this number could be increased to six or reduced to two depending on the bay width. The outer leaves were designed to be removable and fixed, while the central leaves operated as conventional swing doors. Each door leaf was vertically divided into three sections: the lattice panel (geyan格眼), the waist rail (yaochuan腰串), and the splash board (zhangshui ban 障水版). In cases where multiple waist rails were used, decorative panels (yaohua ban 腰華版) could be installed between them. The height ratio between the lattice panel and splash board could be either 2:1 or 1:1. The lattice patterns came in three varieties: diamond-shaped (linghua ge 菱花格), ball-pattern (qiuwen ge 毬文格), and rectangular (zhifang ge直方格). A double-layered version with lattice work on both sides was known as a 'double-sided lattice door' (liangming gezi men 兩明格子門).(Li 2009, 7.1b-3b)

The construction of lattice doors followed the cross-sectional specifications of door frames (teng), which indicated different hierarchical grades. Scholars including Liang Sicheng, Pan Guxi, and Takeshi Taketoshi, generally agree that more complex designs corresponded to higher status levels. （Liang 2001, 195; Pan 2005, 113; Zhudao 1971, 286）
格子門是中國古代建築的門的形式之一，因其上部安裝格眼而命名，記載於《營造法式》（李 2009，7.1b-3b）和《梓人遺製》（薛 1522，3518.4a-16b），但至遲在唐代繪畫中已可見到格子門的形象（唐代李思訓《江帆樓閣圖》）。 這種形式的門及其“格子門”的名稱沿用至清，但在清官式文獻中一般稱為“槅扇”。
《營造法式》記載的格子門高約1.88米至3.76米，高寬比例約10:3。通常每間分作四扇，可隨間廣增至六扇或減至兩扇。外側兩扇為可拆卸的固定式，中間平開啟閉。門扇上下劃分為三部分：格眼，腰串，障水版。 若非單腰串，腰串間可安裝腰華版。格眼與障水版高度比例可為2:1或1:1。格眼分為菱花格，毬文格和直方格。又可作內外雙層，名為兩明格子門。
格子門依照桯的斷面做法，存在等級規格之分，學者普遍認為越繁複等級越高（梁，2001，195；潘，2005,113；竹岛,1971,286）。
